{{Infobox convention | name = Philcon II, the 11th World Science Fiction Convention | image = [[File:BellevueStratford.jpg|200px]] | caption = The Bellevue Stratford Hotel | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = [[Bellevue-Stratford Hotel]] | location = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] | country = United States | first = September 5–7, 1953 | last = | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 750 | website = }} The '''11th World Science Fiction Convention''', also known as '''Philcon II''', was held in September 1953 at the [[Bellevue-Stratford Hotel]] in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], USA. It was the first [[Worldcon]] to present the [[Hugo Award]]s. The supporting organization was the [[Philadelphia Science Fiction Society]]. The guest of honor was [[Willy Ley]]. The chairman was [[Milton A. Rothman]], replacing the late James A. Williams. [[Isaac Asimov]] was [[toastmaster]]. ==Awards== {{About-Hugos}} The 11th Worldcon was the first one in which Hugo Awards were awarded. The 12th convention did not continue the tradition, but since the 13th convention, Hugo Awards have been a permanent fixture of Worldcons. ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[The Demolished Man]]'' by [[Alfred Bester]] [''Galaxy'' January, February, March 1952; Shasta, 1951] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Magazine|Best Professional Magazine]]: (tie) ** ''[[Astounding Science Fiction]]'' edited by [[John W. Campbell, Jr.]] ** ''[[Galaxy Science Fiction]]'' edited by [[H. L. Gold]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Cover Artist]]: (tie) ** [[Hannes Bok]] ** [[Ed Emshwiller]] * [[Other Hugo Awards#Best Interior Illustrator|Best Interior Illustrator]]: [[Virgil Finlay]] * [[Other Hugo Awards#Excellence in Fact Articles|Excellence in Fact Articles]]: [[Willy Ley]] * [[Other Hugo Awards#Best New SF Author or Artist|Best New SF Author or Artist]]: [[Philip José Farmer]] * [[Other Hugo Awards|#1 Fan Personality]]: [[Forrest J. Ackerman]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |work=Notes on the Long List of Worldcons |publisher=[[World Science Fiction Society]] |title=19533 - 11th Worldcon |url=http://www.smofinfo.com/LL/LongListNotes.html#1953 |accessdate=March 7, 2011}} {{cite web |work=The Hugo Awards |title=1953 Hugo Awards |publisher=[[World Science Fiction Society]] |url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1953-hugo-awards/ |accessdate=March 7, 2011}} {{cite news |work=[[The New York Times]] |title=James A. Williams |page=31 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1953/03/24/archives/james-a-williams.html |date=March 24, 1953 |accessdate=January 19, 2011}} {{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The Spokesman-Review]] |page=12 |title=Journey to Moon Beckons World Science Fiction Meet |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XHpWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JuYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1947,1404955&dq=world+science+fiction+convention&hl=en |date=September 5, 1953 |accessdate=January 19, 2011}} {{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[Spokane Daily Chronicle]] |title=Science-Fiction Fans Meet in Philadelphia |page=6 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=m_NXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gvYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7101,1549517&dq=world+science+fiction+convention&hl=en |date=September 5, 1953 |accessdate=January 19, 2011}} {{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[Eugene Register-Guard]] |title=Fiction Fans Talk Science |page=2A |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NBdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tuIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3204,3849901&dq=world+science+fiction+convention&hl=en |date=September 6, 1953 |accessdate=January 19, 2011}} {{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |title=Space Fans, Scientists To Discuss Trip to Moon |page=20 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NhwNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k2oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2377,1633552&dq=world-science-fiction&hl=en |date=September 5, 1953 |accessdate=March 7, 2011}} }} ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *[[World Science Fiction Society]] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[10th World Science Fiction Convention]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{refimprove|date=November 2011}} The '''Libyan hostage situation''' began on the morning of the [[Murder of Yvonne Fletcher|murder of WPC Fletcher]], 17 April 1984 and lasted until 5 February 1985 (294 days). In accordance with the hostage release agreement, reporting on the incident was restricted until the fall of Gadaffi in 2011.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}}
== Timeline ==
'''March 1984'''
Four Libyan nationals were arrested on charges following explosions at Manchester and Heathrow airports in the UK and were remanded in custody.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1079/is_v87/ai_4679424/ Libya – statement by Larry Pressler in a session of the UN General Assembly on November 19, 1986], [[CBS]] Interactive Business Network Resource Library</ref>
'''17 April 1984'''
[[Murder of Yvonne Fletcher|WPC Yvonne Fletcher]] was hit by a bullet from a burst of machine-gun fire from within the Libyan Peoples' Bureau (Libyan Embassy) in St James's Sq., London. She died shortly afterwards.
That evening, Doug Ledingham, the airport manager for British Caledonian Airways at Tripoli Universal Airport, Libya, was arrested by soldiers.
'''17 to 27 April'''
There was a standoff between the Libyan and British governments over the pursuit of who shot WPC Fletcher. The standoff resulted in the breaking of diplomatic relations by Britain with Libya, and the return to Libya under diplomatic immunity of the occupants of the Libyan Peoples' Bureau in London. Rumours abounded at the time as to the fate of the person who is alleged to have fired the fatal shots from the Libyan People's Bureau. In 1986, a British businessman who had worked for Colonel Gaddafi's regime reported WPC Fletcher's killer had been hanged as soon as he returned to Libya.<ref>{{citation |publisher=BBC | series = On this Date | chapter = Stories | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/april/17/newsid_2488000/2488369.stm | title = Libyan embassy shots kill policewoman | date = 17 April 1984}}.</ref>
Following the breaking of diplomatic relations with Libya, the British Embassy in Tripoli was evacuated by the British and ransacked by the Libyans.<ref>{{citation |publisher=BBC | series = On this Date | chapter = Stories | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/april/27/newsid_2502000/2502565.stm | title = 1984: Libyan embassy siege ends | date = 27 April 1984}}</ref> A skeleton staff of British diplomats took up office in the Italian Embassy.
'''14–16 May 1984'''
Four further British men in Libya were rounded up and detained as hostages against the four arrested Libyan nationals in Britain by those claiming to be officials of the [[Muammar Gaddafi|Gaddafi regime]]. The men in order of capture were: Michael Berdinner, Alan Russell, Malcolm Anderson and Robin Plummer. At first, Allen Russell and Malcolm Anderson were held at a separate location where they were questioned and beaten. Ledingham, Berdinner and Plummer (Plummer in solitary confinement) were in the same facility, the Italian Mansion, a building approximately 400 yards distant from the Italian Embassy.
'''12 June 1984'''
A month after being taken hostage, the five men were allowed a meeting with the British Second Consul, George Anderson, who was able to offer only pastoral care and contact with home, but no suggestion of release. It was clear by this time, however, that the men were being held as hostages by one of Col Gaddafi's Revolutionary Committees, in defiance of international law. Return to their respective prisons was followed by little or no improvement in the hostages' circumstances.
'''19 July 1984'''
A second meeting with George Anderson resulted in all the hostages being put into one location, the Italian Mansion, and being fed an improved diet and given medical attention. This improvement in circumstances was accompanied by a slow but inexorable descent into gloom of the hostages isolated from all news of the outside world.
Meanwhile, in Britain, unbeknownst to the hostages, their families, notably Pat Plummer<ref>{{cite video |people= [[Selena Scott]]|date= 3 September 1984|title= Selena Scott interviews Pat Plummer|medium= Television production|publisher=[[ITN]]}}</ref> and Carole Russell,<ref>{{cite video |date=October 1984 |title= After Carole's visit to Libya|medium= Television production|publisher=[[Anglia News]]}}</ref> were working tirelessly with [[Kate Adie]] of the BBC and [[Brent Sadler]] of ITN to keep the hostages' plight in the media to keep the situation in the news and the profile high on the government's agenda. By now, the families were being kept up to date on a daily basis by contacts within the Foreign and Commonwealth Office in London as to the stalemate between Libya and Britain, with a continual decline in international relations between Libya and most of the rest of the world.
'''Summer 1984'''
In London, a committee in parliament was held to determine whether or not what the British government had done over the Libyan hostage situation was reasonable. The committee concluded that in the circumstances, the British government had done all it reasonably could in the light of what little was known at the time.
'''7 August 1984'''
The Libyans allowed family members to visit the hostages. These visits brought unofficial news of the, as yet, publicly undisclosed involvement of [[Terry Waite]], the Special Envoy to the Archbishop of Canterbury, of the Church of England.<ref>[[Terry Waite]], ''Taken on Trust'', 1993, Hodder and Stoughton, UK</ref>
'''1 September 1984'''
Doug Ledingham and George Bush, another prisoner, arrested and detained on bona fide charges unrelated to the Libyan hostage situation, were freed and allowed home.<ref>{{cite video |people= [[Kate Adie]]|date=2 September 1984 |title= Doug Ledingham returns home, Pat Plummer insists the government do more|medium= Television production|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref> On the day of their release, British television news was granted access to and showed the world for the first time, detail of the hostage situation.<ref>{{cite video |people= [[Brent Sadler]]|date=1 September 1984 |title= New moves could help the four Britons held in Libya and the two who come home tomorrow|medium= Television production|publisher=[[ITN News]]}}</ref>
'''17 October 1984'''
Two of the wives of the hostages, Pat Plummer and Carole Russell, attended a meeting with the Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]]. The two wives petitioned for a representative of the British Government to go to Libya and start negotiations for the release of the hostages.<ref>{{cite video |people= Tony Scase|date=17 October 1984 |title= Post meeting with Margaret Thatcher|medium= Television production|publisher=[[BBC Look East]]}}</ref> This meeting was soon followed by the arrival in Libya of Terry Waite.
'''21 October 1984'''
Alan Russell and Malcolm Anderson were removed from the Italian Mansion and taken to the Libyan courts, where they were charged with transporting state secrets.<ref>{{cite video |people= [[Kate Adie]]|date=21 October 1984 |title= Russell and Anderson charged with espionage|medium= Television production|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref>
'''10–18 November 1984'''
Terry Waite was in Libya. The hostage situation showed no signs of thawing, in spite of national and international efforts to secure the release of the hostages and the intervention at a pastoral level of Waite.
'''13–14 December 1984 '''
Allen Russell was placed on trial and charged with sharing state secrets with British journalists. Robin Plummer seized the opportunity to speak to the press post being question and states his innocence and makes a plea for warm clothing.<ref>{{cite video |people= [[Kate Adie]]|date=14 December 1984 |title= Wives plead to Gaddafi and Plummer pleas for warm clothes|medium= Television production|publisher=[[BBC Look East]]}}</ref>
'''24 December 1984'''
The four men were confirmed as political hostages by Gaddafi. Waite held a Christmas carol service with the hostages.<ref>{{cite video |people= [[Kate Adie]]|date=24 December 1984 |title= A difficult Christmas|medium= Television production|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref>
'''6 January 1985'''
Col Gaddafi himself placed the matter of the remaining hostages before the members of the Basic and General Peoples' Congresses, the system of democracy prevalent in Libya at the time, for a decision on the release of the hostages.
'''1 February 1985'''
Then WPC Fletcher's memorial was unveiled temporarily disrupting negotiations and sent a very clear message to the Libyans.
'''5 February 1985'''
The Congresses voted by an overwhelming majority to release the hostages. But there were conditions to the release.<ref>{{cite video |people= [[Kate Adie]]|date=5 February 1985 |title= Press Conference in Libya to release hostages|medium= Television production|publisher=[[BBC]] Breakfast}}</ref> The release was however subject to a few days' delay, for undisclosed reasons.
'''7 February 1985'''
After almost nine months (294 days), the hostages arrived back in England.<ref>{{cite video |date=7 February 1985 |title= Former Hostages arrive at Gatwick|medium= Television production|publisher=[[BBC]] Breakfast}}</ref>
== Conditions for release == {{unreferenced section|date=June 2015}}
The conditions were as follows:{{Citation needed|date=June 2015}} #Britain should undertake not to support "stray dogs" (political exiles),<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/mar/28/politics.libya Gadaffi still hunts 'stray dogs' in UK], Martin Bright, ''[[The Observer]]'', Sunday 28 March 2004</ref>{{failed verification|date=June 2015}} to hand them over, and to stop antagonistic acts against the Libyan people; #British Government to work for release of the Libyan prisoners in the UK; #The Anglican Church to undertake to look after Libyan students in Britain and to endeavour to secure release of Libyan prisoners; #British Government to stop anti-Libyan propaganda channelled through British media; #Her Majesty's Government to undertake to treat Libyans in accordance with international law.
== Aftermath == {{unreferenced section|date=June 2015}} An interpretation of Condition 4 could include a complete absence in any British-controlled media of any reference to the Libyan hostage situation for fear that any such reference might be construed by the Libyan authorities as a breach of Condition 4. In accordance with this interpretation, there has been almost no reference to the hostage situation in literature since the time of the release. Most references that state the history of Libya at the time make reference to the murder of WPC Fletcher and then make no reference whatsoever to the hostage situation, skipping instead to the bombing of Libya by the Americans in 1986.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}

casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | fatalities = 1 | injuries = 3 | arrests = 2 | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = | sidebox = }} A [[constitutional crisis]] began in [[Sri Lanka]] when President [[Maithripala Sirisena]] appointed former president and member of parliament [[Mahinda Rajapaksa]] as [[Prime Minister of Sri Lanka|prime minister]] on 26 October 2018 before formally dismissing the incumbent [[Ranil Wickremesinghe]], resulting in two concurrent prime ministers. Wickremesinghe and the [[United National Party]] (UNP) viewed the appointment as illegal, and he refused to resign.{{cite web |last1=Meixler |first1=Eli |title=Sri Lankan Strongman's Return Sparks 'Constitutional Crisis' |url=http://time.com/5437457/sri-lanka-mahinda-rajapaksa-president-crisis/ |website=Time |accessdate=11 November 2018 }} Sirisena's sudden decision instigated "political turmoil in the country", and drew international criticism.{{cite web |last1=Aneez |first1=Shihar |title=Sri Lanka PM, 44 ex-MPs defect from party led by president ahead of election |url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/sri-lanka-pm--44-ex-mps-defect-from-party-led-by-president-ahead-of-election-10919188 |publisher=Channel NewsAsia |accessdate=14 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-46019280|title=Sri Lanka crisis: Fears of a 'bloodbath' in power struggle|publisher=BBC|accessdate=31 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181030132740/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-46019280#|archive-date=30 October 2018|dead-url=no}}{{cite web |last1=Rasheed |first1=Zaheena |title=Sri Lanka president sacks prime minister, appoints Rajapaksa |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/10/sri-lanka-president-sacks-prime-minister-appoints-rajapaksa-181026174208405.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=31 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181031003927/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/10/sri-lanka-president-sacks-prime-minister-appoints-rajapaksa-181026174208405.html# |archive-date=31 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} Wickremesinghe, the majority of the [[Parliament of Sri Lanka|parliament]], and opposition parties refused to acknowledge his removal and the appointment of Rajapaksa, stating that Sirisena's move was unconstitutional.{{cite web |title=The tale of two Prime Ministers |url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/181028/news/the-tale-of-two-prime-ministers-317883.html |website=The Sunday Times Sri Lanka |accessdate=11 November 2018}} Wickremesinghe claimed that he still commands a majority in parliament and requested that [[Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka|Speaker of the Parliament]] [[Karu Jayasuriya]] convene parliament immediately.{{Cite web |url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1834753/3-sri-lanka-president-sacks-pm-plunges-country-crisis/# |title=Sri Lanka President sacks PM, plunges country into crisis |access-date=28 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181028102555/https://tribune.com.pk/story/1834753/3-sri-lanka-president-sacks-pm-plunges-country-crisis/# |archive-date=28 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} Sirisena ignored all calls to reconvene parliament and on 27 October [[prorogued]] parliament, delaying its meeting till 16 November.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/-Parliament-prorogued-157481.html# |title=Parliament prorogued |access-date=28 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181028074017/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/-Parliament-prorogued-157481.html# |archive-date=28 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} After an attempt to form a new [[Cabinet of Sri Lanka|cabinet of ministers]] with Rajapaksa as prime minister failed, Sirisena attempted to dissolve parliament on 9 November. The UNP declared the move unconstitutional and subsequently the [[Supreme Court of Sri Lanka|Supreme Court]] has stayed Sirisena's dissolution until December 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/article/1053948/unp-to-challenge-presidents-gazette-to-dissolve-parliament-on-monday|title=Sunday Times – UNP to challenge President's gazette to dissolve Parliament on Monday|website=sundaytimes.lk}} Rajapaksa has been a controversial figure in Sri Lanka since the [[Sri Lankan Civil War]]. He and [[Rajapaksa family|his close family]] have been accused of and are currently under investigation for [[corruption]]. The fate of the corruption cases targeting members of the Rajapaksa family, along with investigations into the murders of journalists and others during the Rajapaksa presidency (2005–2015), are unknown due to the present crisis.{{cite web |title=India scrambles to claw back ground in Sri Lanka after pro-China leader named PM |url=http://www.ft.lk/news/India-scrambles-to-claw-back-ground-in-Sri-Lanka-after-pro-China-leader-named-PM/56-665738 |website=t.lk |publisher=Wijeya Newspapers Ltd. |accessdate=31 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181030131243/http://www.ft.lk/news/India-scrambles-to-claw-back-ground-in-Sri-Lanka-after-pro-China-leader-named-PM/56-665738# |archive-date=30 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} {{TOC limit|3}} ==Background== ===Rajapaksa presidency=== The presidency of Mahinda Rajapaksa, from 2005 to 2015 was an increasingly authoritarian regime{{cite web |title=The Guardian view on the end of the Rajapaksa era in Sri Lanka {{!}} Editorial |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/jan/11/guardian-view-on-end-of-rajapaksa-era-sri-lanka-sirisena |website=The Guardian |accessdate=10 November 2018 |date=11 January 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180912212923/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/jan/11/guardian-view-on-end-of-rajapaksa-era-sri-lanka-sirisena# |archive-date=12 September 2018 |dead-url=no }} characterised by the diminishing [[Human rights in Sri Lanka|human rights in the country]], [[nepotism]], weakening of government institutions, slow progress of national reconciliation in the [[aftermath of the Sri Lankan Civil War]], and [[China–Sri Lanka relations|close ties to China]]. Before serving as president, Rajapaksa also served as Prime Minister. In 2009, Rajapaksa ended the 27-year long [[Sri Lankan Civil War]], but has been accused of [[war crime]]s and human rights abuses.{{cite web |last1=Bastians |first1=Dharisha |last2=Gettleman |first2=Jeffrey |title=Bribery Accusations Deepen Turmoil in Sri Lanka |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/02/world/asia/sri-lanka-prime-minister-bribery-crisis.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181102220318/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/02/world/asia/sri-lanka-prime-minister-bribery-crisis.html# |archive-date=2 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} At the height of his power, Rajapaksa and [[Rajapaksa family|his family]] controlled 80 percent of the national budget where Rajapaksa simultaneously served as finance minister and four other cabinet posts on top of the presidency, while his three brothers served as the defence secretary and ministers of economy and ports and the [[Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka|Speaker of the Parliament]]. Many of those, including journalists, who were critical of him disappeared. According to [[Reuters]], in the aftermath of the Sri Lankan Civil War, Rajapaksa borrowed "billions of dollars" from China to build infrastructure projects, though these had little economic value to the country.{{cite web |last1=Schneider |first1=Kate |title=$282 million airport has a huge problem |url=https://www.news.com.au/travel/travel-advice/flights/282-million-airport-has-a-huge-problem/news-story/e080d0b290141a2a9f4f84fc8827c353 |website=NewsComAu |accessdate=11 November 2018}}{{cite web |last1=Marlow |first1=Iain |title=Bloomberg – Are you a robot? |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-17/china-s-1-billion-white-elephant-the-port-ships-don-t-use |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |accessdate=11 November 2018}} These projects were seen as vanity projects or [[white elephant]]s.{{cite web |last1=Aneez |first1=Aneez |last2=Sirilal |first2=Ranga |title=Turmoil in Sri Lanka as Ex-President Rajapaksa Sworn in as PM |url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2018/10/26/world/asia/26reuters-sri-lanka-politics.html?action=click&module=RelatedCoverage&pgtype=Article®ion=Footer |website=The New York Times |accessdate=3 November 2018 }}{{dead link|date=November 2018}} ===2015 presidential election=== In response to the degrading democracy in the country, the [[United National Party]] (UNP), along with several other parties and civil organisations, signed a [[Memorandum of Understanding]] and decided to field the then Secretary General of [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party]] (SLFP), [[Maithripala Sirisena]], as the Common Candidate for the [[Sri Lankan presidential election, 2015|2015 Presidential Election]]. Sirisena, a former health minister under Rajapaksa, pledged to appoint UNP Leader [[Ranil Wickremesinghe]] as the Prime Minister if he were to win the election.{{cite web |last1=Abi-Habib |first1=Maria |last2=Bastians |first2=Dharisha |title=Sri Lanka Faces Constitutional Crisis as President Unseats Prime Minister |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/26/world/asia/sri-lanka-political-crisis.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=31 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181101015327/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/26/world/asia/sri-lanka-political-crisis.html# |archive-date=1 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} Sirisena won the January 2015 election and became the 7th President of Sri Lanka and appointed Wickremesinghe as the Prime Minister as promised. The presidential election was followed by a [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 2015|General Parliamentary Elections]], held on 17 August 2015, in which the UNP-lead coalition gained 106 seats in the Parliament and formed a National Government with several other parties. Wickremesinghe and the UNP came to power promising accountability for alleged atrocities committed during the [[Sri Lanka civil war]] and during the Rajapaksa presidency. Following the 2015 election defeat, Mahinda Rajapaksa held India's intelligence service, [[Research and Analysis Wing]] (RAW), among those responsible for the change in regime. The [[Government of India]] also welcomed Rajapaksa's defeat, claiming that the former leader had strained ties with them while moving the country closer to China. A [[national unity government#Sri Lanka|national unity government]] was formed, which passed the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the Constitution of Sri Lanka]] on 28 April 2015, stipulating that the prime minister should remain in office for as long as his cabinet functions, unless he resigns or ceases to be a member of parliament.{{cite web |title=Nineteenth Amendment to the Constitution of Sri Lanka |url=http://slembassyusa.org/downloads/19th_Amendment_E.pdf |publisher=Gazette of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka |accessdate=31 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180929113428/http://slembassyusa.org/downloads/19th_Amendment_E.pdf# |archive-date=29 September 2018 |dead-url=no }} ===Uneasy coalition=== The Sirisena-Wickremesinghe government had been struggling to repay the debts incurred during the Rajapaksa presidency. The [[Magampura Mahinda Rajapaksa Port]], built with Chinese money, was handed over to Beijing in a 99-year lease in 2017 as a form of payment. Sri Lanka also recorded just 3.1% [[Economic growth|economic growth rate]], the lowest for 16 years in 2017.{{cite news|title= Sri Lanka’s economic growth in 2017 fell to 16 year-low|url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/article/1042630/sls-economic-growth-in-2017-fell-to-17-year-low|accessdate=15 May 2018|agency=menafn.com|publisher=menafn.com|date=26 April 2018}} By 2018, following Mahinda Rajapaksa's proxy [[Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna]] winning a landslide victory in the [[Sri Lankan local elections, 2018|2018 local authority elections]], disputes among the members of the National Government began to surface and a major rift between the President and Prime Minister appeared.{{cite news|last1=Aneez|first1=Shihar|last2=Srilal|first2=Ranga|title=Sri Lanka ex-leader-backed party set for landslide victory in local polls|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sri-lanka-politics/sri-lanka-ex-leader-backed-party-set-for-landslide-victory-in-local-polls-idUSKBN1FV07C|accessdate=11 February 2018|agency=Reuters|date=11 February 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180211072606/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sri-lanka-politics/sri-lanka-ex-leader-backed-party-set-for-landslide-victory-in-local-polls-idUSKBN1FV07C#|archive-date=11 February 2018|dead-url=no}} Sirisena claimed Wickremesinghe to have led to the loss of 11 billion Sri Lankan rupees ($65 million; £50 million) in the [[Ranil Wickremesinghe#Government bonds controversy|controversial central bank bond sale]], and also alleged that a cabinet minister was involved in a plot to kill him and that police had obstructed an investigation. In 2017 opinion poll conducted by the Centre for Policy Alternatives revealed Fifty-six percent of respondents are unhappy with the coalition government. Specially 63 percent of majority [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]] respondents.{{cite news|title= Beginning of end for Sri Lanka’s coalition government|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Beginning-of-end-for-Sri-Lanka-s-coalition-government-147271.html|accessdate=26 November 2018|publisher=dailymirror.lk|date=15 March 2018}} ===Special high courts for bribery and corruption cases=== In May 2018, the Sri Lanka parliament approved a [[High Court of Sri Lanka#Special High Court|special high court]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sri-lanka-corruption-court/sri-lanka-parliament-backs-special-courts-for-bribery-corruption-cases-idUSKBN1IA2QE|title=Sri Lanka parliament backs special courts for bribery, corruption...|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-11-19|language=en-US}} that would expedite the hearing and trial of bribery and corruption related cases. The concept for the [[High Court]] [[Bench trial|Trial-at-Bar]] was instituted with the passage of amendments to the Judicature Act, the purpose of expediting cases from the Rajapaksa Government era.{{Cite web|url=http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=188351|title=The Island|last=LTD|first=Lankacom PVT|website=www.island.lk|access-date=2018-11-19}} The ''Sunday Times'' of 15 July 2018 stated that "the former Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation chairman Gamini Senarath and its Managing Director Piyadasa Kudabalage will be the first to be indicted before the newly set up court."{{cite web |last1=Chandraprema |first1=C.A. |title=Yahapalana law and the Judiciary: Hauling the Rajapaksas before a Special High Court |url=http://www.lankaweb.com/news/items/2018/07/21/yahapalana-law-and-the-judiciary-hauling-the-rajapaksas-before-a-special-high-court/ |publisher=LankaWeb |accessdate=20 November 2018 |date=21 July 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Cases-against-Senarath-and-Kudabalage-The-first-to-be-heard-by-the-Trial-at-Bar-154239.html|title=Cases against Senarath and Kudabalage: The first to be heard by the Trial at Bar|access-date=2018-11-19|language=en}} Senarath was the chief of staff of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa. The Special Courts are also strongly regarded as a factor in the creation of the 2018 Constitutional Crisis. ===Alleged assassination attempt=== Reports of an assassination plot emerged in September when an individual named Namal Kumara claimed he was aware of a plan to assassinate President Sirisena and former Defence Secretary [[Gotabaya Rajapaksa]]. Kumara was interrogated by the [[Criminal Investigation Department (Sri Lanka)|Criminal Investigation Department]] (CID), and in late September the police arrested an Indian national, Marceli Thomas, from Kerala, claiming he knew of the plot. Kumara alleged the Director of the Terrorism Investigation Division (TID) of the [[Sri Lanka Police]], [[Deputy Inspector General of Police]] [[Nalaka de Silva]] had masterminded the plot.{{cite web |title=Indian Held Over Plot To Kill Sri Lanka President Sent To Mental Hospital |url=https://www.ndtv.com/indians-abroad/marceli-thomas-indian-held-over-plot-to-kill-sri-lanka-president-maithripala-sirisena-sent-to-mental-1938317 |website=''NDTV.com'' |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107024652/https://www.ndtv.com/indians-abroad/marceli-thomas-indian-held-over-plot-to-kill-sri-lanka-president-maithripala-sirisena-sent-to-mental-1938317# |archive-date=7 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} Nalaka de Silva was suspended pending a formal investigation by the CID and later arrested by CID on 25 October under the [[Prevention of Terrorism Act (Sri Lanka)|Prevention of Terrorism Act]] and remanded till 7 November.{{cite web |title=Former TID DIG Nalaka de Silva remanded |url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2018/10/26/law-order/166659/former-tid-dig-nalaka-de-silva-remanded |website=Daily News |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181028164640/http://www.dailynews.lk/2018/10/26/law-order/166659/former-tid-dig-nalaka-de-silva-remanded# |archive-date=28 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} In mid October 2018, Indian newspaper ''[[The Hindu]]'' reported that Sirisena told Cabinet members that India's intelligence service, [[Research and Analysis Wing]] (RAW), had devised a plot to assassinate him, though Sirisena denied the report.{{cite web |last1=Srinivasan |first1=Meera |title=Sri Lankan President Sirisena alleges that RAW is plotting his assassination |url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/sri-lankan-president-sirisena-alleges-that-raw-is-plotting-his-assassination/article25241800.ece |website=The Hindu |accessdate=3 November 2018 |date=16 October 2018}} Sirisena in the cabinet meeting told Ministers that RAW was "trying to kill" him, but "Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] may not be aware of the plan." On 18 October 2018, a statement released by India's [[Prime Minister's Office (India)|Prime Minister Office]] (PMO) said that Sirisena called Indian Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] to reject the media reports about him alluding to the involvement of India in the alleged assassination plot. Sirisena also stated that he "regards the [Indian] prime minister as a true friend of Sri Lanka, as also a close personal friend. He stressed that he greatly valued the mutually beneficial ties between India and Sri Lanka, and remained steadfast to work with the prime minister for further strengthening them."{{cite web |last1=Mohan |first1=Geeta|title=Sri Lanka denies reports of India plotting to assassinate President Sirisena|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/mail-today/story/sri-lanka-denies-reports-of-india-plotting-to-assassinate-president-sirisena-1370253-2018-10-18 |website=[[India Today]] |accessdate=23 November 2018 |date=18 October 2018}} On 26 October 2018, the [[United People's Freedom Alliance]] (UPFA) withdrew from the government, ending the national government that was in place since 2015.{{cite web |title=UPFA withdraws from Govt. |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/UPFA-withdraws-from-Govt--157433.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181028151543/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/UPFA-withdraws-from-Govt--157433.html# |archive-date=28 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} The same day, Sirisena also alleged that a cabinet minister was involved but did not name the cabinet minister. However said "Under these political problems, economic troubles, and the strong plot to assassinate me, the only alternative open to me was to invite former president Mahinda Rajapaksa and appoint him as prime minister to form a new government." ==Timeline of events== ===Two prime ministers=== The president's UPFA had earlier on Friday, 26 October, quit the national unity government that had governed with Prime Minister [[Ranil Wickremesinghe]]'s UNP. Later at about 7:00 pm without a prior announcement, President [[Maithripala Sirisena]] unexpectedly appointed former President Mahinda Rajapaksa as Prime Minister in a live swearing-in ceremony broadcast over television. Rajapaksa took an oath of office in the presence of Sirisena and representatives of the military inside the [[Presidential Secretariat]]. He was sworn in while Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe was still the incumbent and away touring in the south of the country. The situation in Colombo was uneasy with some cabinet ministers immediately declaring the move unconstitutional, while other Cabinet ministers and parliamentarians began defecting to the new government. Wickremesinghe addressed the nation saying, "I am addressing you as the prime minister of Sri Lanka. I still hold the majority of the house. [...] Convene parliament and I will prove it." Three ministers, including [[Mangala Samaraweera]] and Cabinet Spokesman [[Rajitha Senaratne]], tried to address the nation during a live television program. That day Rajapaksa loyalists stormed two state-owned television networks which they regarded loyal to Wickremesinghe and the sitting government, including [[Rupavahini]], and forced them off the air. Troops were brought in to protect the channel's staff.{{cite web |last1=Chaudhury |first1=Dipanjan Roy |title=Ranil Wickremesinghe refuses to step down as Sri Lankan PM |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/ranil-wickremesinghe-refuses-to-step-down-as-sri-lankan-pm/articleshow/66388881.cms |website=The Economic Times |accessdate=31 October 2018 |date=27 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181101002712/https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/ranil-wickremesinghe-refuses-to-step-down-as-sri-lankan-pm/articleshow/66388881.cms?utm_source=contentofinterest&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=cppst# |archive-date=1 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} Finance Minister [[Mangala Samaraweera]] tweeted that Rajapaksa's appointment was "unconstitutional and illegal. This is an anti-democratic coup," saying Wickramasinghe remained leader as he could not constitutionally be removed by the president.{{cite web |last1=Samaraweera |first1=Mangala |title=Mangala Samaraweera on Twitter |url=https://twitter.com/MangalaLK/status/1055838461112967168 |website=Twitter |accessdate=3 November 2018 }}{{Primary source inline|date=November 2018}}{{cite web |title=PM's 'sacking' leaves Sri Lanka in turmoil |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-45991919 |work=BBC News|accessdate=3 November 2018 |date=26 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104024650/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-45991919# |archive-date=4 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} While UPFA MP [[Susil Premajayantha]] told reporters that a new cabinet would be sworn in soon. [[Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka|Speaker of the Parliament]] [[Karu Jayasuriya]] said he was to decide on Saturday (27th), after seeking legal advice, whether to recognise Rajapaksa or not. The Parliament was not due to meet until 5 November when the 2019 national budget was to be presented. The [[Supreme Court of Sri Lanka|Supreme Court]], which is empowered to resolve constitutional disputes, was shut for the weekend, to be reopened on Monday. On 27 October President Sirisena issued a formal notice for Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe to step down. Sirisena later issued gazettes formalising and defending the dramatic move. Wickremesinghe however entered [[Temple Trees]], the Prime Ministers residence, refusing to accept the appointment of Mahinda Rajapaksa and his dismissal, insisting in a letter to Sirisena that he was still in office. Sirisena and Rajapaksa announced their intent to form a new cabinet. Nalaka Kaluwewa, an Acting Additional Secretary in the [[Presidential Secretariat]], was appointed as Acting Director General of Information under the instructions of President Sirisena.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Nalaka-Kaluwewa-appointed-Actg-Director-General-of-Information-157485.html# |title=Nalaka Kaluwewa appointed Actg Director General of Information |access-date=28 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181028151540/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Nalaka-Kaluwewa-appointed-Actg-Director-General-of-Information-157485.html# |archive-date=28 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} The day after Rajapaksa's appointment, the Parliament, which was due to meet on 5 November to discuss the budget for the next year, was [[prorogued]] by the President, delaying its meeting till 16 November. President Sirisena stated on Saturday night that the main reason for him to form a new government with Mahinda Rajapaksa as Prime Minister was the alleged plot to assassinate him. He claimed that the name of [[Sarath Fonseka]] had come up in the investigation of the CID but was suppressed.{{cite web |title=President says plot linked to Fonseka was game changer |url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/181028/news/president-says-plot-linked-to-fonseka-was-game-changer-317875.html |website=The Sunday Times Sri Lanka |accessdate=11 November 2018}} On 27 October, [[Mangala Samaraweera]] tweeted that the security personnel and official verticals assigned to the Prime Minister were withdrawn from Wickremesinghe and assigned to Rajapaksa on orders from the President.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/MangalaLK/status/1056185186247880704|title=Mangala Samaraweera on Twitter}}{{Primary source inline|date=November 2018}} The [[Inspector General of Police (Sri Lanka)|Inspector General of Police]] (IGP) [[Pujith Jayasundara|Jayasundara]] had ordered the 1,008 police and [[Special Task Force|STF]] personnel assigned to Wickremesinghe as [[Prime Minister's Security Division|prime ministerial security]] to be withdrawn and replaced with 10 police personnel from the Ministerial Security Division (MSD). The security details of ministers of the former government have been also reduced to the levels provided to parliamentarians.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Security-details-of-ex-ministers-to-be-reduced-157609.html# |title=Security details of ex-ministers to be reduced |access-date=30 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181030103016/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Security-details-of-ex-ministers-to-be-reduced-157609.html# |archive-date=30 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} China, Burundi and Pakistan had recognised Mahinda Rajapaksa as Prime minister. Chinese President [[Xi Jinping]] was one of the first to congratulate the pro-Beijing leader.{{cite web |title=After China, Burundi, Pakistan Recognises Rajapaksa as Lankan Prime Minister |url=https://www.news18.com/news/world/after-china-burundi-pakistan-recognises-rajapaksa-as-lankan-prime-minister-1927181.html |website=News18 |accessdate=14 November 2018}} ===Calls to reconvene Parliament=== [[File:Karu Jayasuriya.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Karu Jayasuriya, Speaker of Parliament]] The [[Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka|Speaker of Parliament]], [[Karu Jayasuriya]] has requested the President to reconvene parliament following consultations with party leaders of the [[United National Party|UNP]], [[Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi|ITAK]], [[Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna|JVP]] and the [[Sri Lanka Muslim Congress|SLMC]] on 30 October.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Reconvene-Parliament-Speaker-makes-kind-request-to-Prez-157618.html# |title=Reconvene Parliament: Speaker makes ‘kind request’ to Prez |access-date=30 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181030102429/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Reconvene-Parliament-Speaker-makes-kind-request-to-Prez-157618.html# |archive-date=30 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} The [[Attorney General]] [[Jayantha Jayasuriya]] stated that it is inappropriate for him to express an opinion on the matter, in response to a request for comment by the Speaker.{{cite web |title=Inappropriate to comment on political crisis AG tells Speaker ::. Latest Sri Lanka News |url=https://www.onlanka.com/news/inappropriate-to-comment-on-political-crisis-ag-tells-speaker.html |website=Onlanka |accessdate=11 November 2018 |date=1 November 2018}}{{cite web |title=PM change: AG says expressing opinion inappropriate |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/PM-change-AG-says-expressing-opinion-inappropriate-157686.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=11 November 2018 }} UPFA MP [[Susil Premajayantha]] stated that Parliament would reconvene on 16 November as per the Gazette and not on 5 November as said by Rajapaksa the day before.{{cite web |title=No change in Parliament date: Susil |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/No-change-in-Parliament-date-Susil-157757.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181103165554/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/No-change-in-Parliament-date-Susil-157757.html# |archive-date=3 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} On 2 November 119 MPs from several parties met and passed a resolution calling for immediate convention of Parliament claiming that the removal of the Prime Minister and the appointment of another was unconstitutional. The Speaker has stated that the President agreed to convene Parliament on 7 November. However, if the President fails to issue the gazette notification to convene Parliament, the Speaker has stated that he will convene Parliament on 7 November under the powers vested in him.{{cite web |title=Majority of Parliamentarians Resolve To Convene Parliament And Claim MR's Appointment As PM Unacceptable |url=https://www.colombotelegraph.com/index.php/majority-of-parliamentarians-resolve-to-convene-parliament-and-claim-mrs-appointment-as-pm-unacceptable/ |website=Colombo Telegraph |accessdate=3 November 2018 |date=2 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104010349/https://www.colombotelegraph.com/index.php/majority-of-parliamentarians-resolve-to-convene-parliament-and-claim-mrs-appointment-as-pm-unacceptable/# |archive-date=4 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} Speaker Jayasuriya later in a statement announced that he will not accept any changes that had happened in Sri Lanka after 26 October until they are verified in parliament.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/I-am-compelled-to-accept-previous-status-in-Parliament-Speaker-157905.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=6 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181106132429/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/I-am-compelled-to-accept-previous-status-in-Parliament-Speaker-157905.html# |archive-date=6 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} On 7 November UPFA MP [[Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena]] said that the only item on Parliamentary agenda on 14 November is the policy statement by President Sirisena.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Only-President-s-speech-on-Lakshman-Yapa-158043.html# |title=Only President's speech on 14: Lakshman Yapa |access-date=9 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107223216/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Only-President-s-speech-on-Lakshman-Yapa-158043.html# |archive-date=7 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} President Sirisena met with a [[Tamil National Alliance]] (TNA) delegation whom he asked to abstain from a vote of no confidence if it were moved. The TNA told Sirisena it had taken a decision to vote against the appointment of Mahinda Rajapaksa as the Prime Minister. The President in response is reported to have said that he will not reappoint Ranil Wickremesinghe as the Prime Minister, even if his party secured a majority in Parliament.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/-President-says-no-to-Ranil--158089.html|title=President says no to Ranil|website=Daily Mirror|accessdate=9 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109174628/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/-President-says-no-to-Ranil--158089.html#|archive-date=9 November 2018|dead-url=no}} While making an address on 8 November the SLFP executive committee meeting Sirisena said that "he had used only one trump card and there were more trump cards still in his hand", and that he would not go back on any decisions that he had taken already, during this crisis. Sirisena said he was going to make a request to the UNP to support the government's work plan when Parliament reconvenes on the 14th.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Used-only-one-trump-card-more-in-hand-President-158105.html|title=Used only one trump card, more in hand: President|website=Daily Mirror|accessdate=9 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109081612/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Used-only-one-trump-card-more-in-hand-President-158105.html#|archive-date=9 November 2018|dead-url=no}} The UNP said it would explore the possibility of removing President Sirisena in conformity with Article 38 (2) of the Constitution. The [[Tamil Progressive Alliance]] (TPA) responded it would not support any impeachment move as, while they do not support the appointment of Rajapaksa, "they are not in favour of adding more fire to the current crisis".{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Won-t-support-impeachment-move-against-President-Mano-158135.html|title=Won't support impeachment move against President: Mano|website=Daily Mirror|accessdate=9 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109093351/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Won-t-support-impeachment-move-against-President-Mano-158135.html#|archive-date=9 November 2018|dead-url=no}} ===Sirisena-Rajapaksa cabinet appointments=== On 29 October, President [[Maithripala Sirisena|Maitripala Sirisena]] appointed the first members of a new cabinet at the [[Presidential Secretariat]] in [[Colombo]], with four UNP MPs appointed as ministers including [[Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe]], [[Vadivel Suresh]], [[Vasantha Senanayake]] and [[Ananda Aluthgamage]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/sri-lankas-president-appoints-new-cabinet-of-ministers/# |title=Sri Lanka's President appoints new cabinet of ministers |access-date=29 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181029200157/http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/sri-lankas-president-appoints-new-cabinet-of-ministers/# |archive-date=29 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} UNP MP [[Dunesh Gankanda]] was sworn in as State Minister of Environment along with a dozen secretaries to various ministries on 30 October.{{Cite web |url=http://www.ft.lk/front-page/Gankanda-sworn-in-as-State-Minister/44-665822# |title=Gankanda sworn in as State Minister |access-date=1 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181101140233/http://www.ft.lk/front-page/Gankanda-sworn-in-as-State-Minister/44-665822# |archive-date=1 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} UNP MP [[Ashoka Priyantha]] was appointed on 4 November as Deputy Minister of Cultural and Internal Affairs, and Regional Development (Wayamba).{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/UNP-MP-Ashoka-gets-Deputy-Minister-portfolio-157874.html# |title=UNP MP Ashoka gets Deputy Minister portfolio |access-date=4 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104170245/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/UNP-MP-Ashoka-gets-Deputy-Minister-portfolio-157874.html# |archive-date=4 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} While UPFA MPs [[Dinesh Gunawardena]] was appointed Minister of Megapolis and Western Development; [[Vasudeva Nanayakkara]], Minister of National Integration, Reconciliation, and Official Languages and [[Keheliya Rambukwella]] State Minister of Mass Media and Digital Infrastructure.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Dinesh-Vasu-gets-new-ministry-portfolios-Keheliya-State-Minister-Media-157873.html# |title=Dinesh, Vasu gets new ministry portfolios, Keheliya State Minister Media |access-date=4 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104144127/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Dinesh-Vasu-gets-new-ministry-portfolios-Keheliya-State-Minister-Media-157873.html# |archive-date=4 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} On 6 November Deputy Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment and UPFA MP Manusha Nanayakkara resigned from his ministerial position and pledged support to Ranil Wickremesinghe. Nanayakkara says that staying true to his heart he cannot join or participate in the recent appointments made and the change in government.{{Cite web |url=http://www.adaderana.lk/news/51244/manusha-gives-up-ministerial-portfolio-supports-ranil# |title=Archived copy |access-date=6 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181106132409/http://www.adaderana.lk/news/51244/manusha-gives-up-ministerial-portfolio-supports-ranil# |archive-date=6 November 2018 |dead-url=no }}{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Manusha-resigns-as-Dy-Minister-157956.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=6 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181106091046/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Manusha-resigns-as-Dy-Minister-157956.html# |archive-date=6 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} ===Bribery allegations=== The UNP has alleged that Rajapaksa loyalists has been luring its MPs to support Sirisena and Rajapaksa with the offer of significant bribes and ministerial portfolios. On 3 November, the UNP released an audio recording, which it claimed an attempt to buy UNP MPs which contained a phone conversation allegedly taken place between UPFA MP [[S. B. Dissanayake]] and UNP MP [[Palitha Range Bandara]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Attempts-to-lure-MPs-UNP-releases-audio-recording-157868.html# |title=Attempts to lure MPs: UNP releases audio recording |access-date=4 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104170251/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Attempts-to-lure-MPs-UNP-releases-audio-recording-157868.html# |archive-date=4 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} UPFA MP [[Dinesh Gunawardena]] was appointed [[Leader of the House (Sri Lanka)|Leader of the House]].{{cite web |title=Dinesh Gunawardena to be new Leader of the House |url=https://colombogazette.com/2018/11/03/dinesh-gunawardena-to-be-new-leader-of-the-house/ |website=Colombo Gazette |accessdate=11 November 2018 |date=3 November 2018}} ===Dissolution of parliament and elections=== President Sirisena issues a gazette notification bringing the [[Sri Lanka Police]] under the purview of the [[Ministry of Defence (Sri Lanka)|Ministry of Defence]], which was earlier under the [[Ministry of Law and Order (Sri Lanka)|Ministry of Law and Order]].{{cite web |title=Police Department brought under Defence Ministry |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Police-Department-brought-under-Defence-Ministry-158141.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=9 November 2018 }} This was followed with the transfer of the Department of Government Printing which publishes the government [[Gazette]] under the Ministry of Defence. Sirisena has brought the Military, Police and the Gazette under his direct control.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Dept-of-Government-Printing-brought-under-President-158156.html# |title=Dept. of Government Printing brought under President |access-date=10 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109174559/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Dept-of-Government-Printing-brought-under-President-158156.html# |archive-date=9 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} Amid calls to reconvene parliament Sirisena and his party admitted they did not have enough votes to support Mahinda Rajapaksa against Ranil Wickremesinghe to decide the office of Prime Minister. Ahead of the president's announcement the UPFA said they were at least eight legislators short of getting a majority for Rajapaksa in the parliament. "At the moment we have 104 or 105 MPs," UPFA's spokesman [[Keheliya Rambukwella]] told reporters. He further went on to say the Sirisena-Rajapakse group hoped to secure support from "crossover" legislators. This is in contrast to what Sirisena claimed on the 5th, that he had the support of 113 legislators when he sacked Wickremesinghe. According to an AFP count, 120 MPs support Wickremesinghe and his allies.{{cite web |title=Sri Lanka president dissolves parliament in bid to end power struggle |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/nov/09/sri-lanka-president-dissolves-parliament-in-bid-to-end-power-struggle |website=The Guardian |accessdate=9 November 2018 |date=9 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109225852/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/nov/09/sri-lanka-president-dissolves-parliament-in-bid-to-end-power-struggle# |archive-date=9 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} President Sirisena dissolves Parliament by proclamation, from midnight of 9 November and declared [[Next Sri Lankan parliamentary election|snap elections]] to be held on around 5 January 2019.{{cite web |last1=Kuruwita |first1=Rathindra |last2=Rasheed |first2=Zaheena |title=Sri Lanka president dissolves parliament, sets January snap poll |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/11/sri-lanka-president-dissolves-parliament-deepening-crisis-181109170918447.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=9 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109203726/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/11/sri-lanka-president-dissolves-parliament-deepening-crisis-181109170918447.html# |archive-date=9 November 2018 |dead-url=no }}{{cite web |last1=Bastians |first1=Dharisha |last2=Goel |first2=Vindu |title=Sri Lanka President Dissolves Parliament Amid Power Struggle |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/09/world/asia/sri-lanka-dissolves-parliament.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=9 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109202613/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/09/world/asia/sri-lanka-dissolves-parliament.html# |archive-date=9 November 2018 |dead-url=no }}{{cite web |title=Parliament dissolved from midnight |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Parliament-dissolved-from-midnight-158179.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=9 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109203810/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Parliament-dissolved-from-midnight-158179.html# |archive-date=9 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} The move was swiftly denounced by the United National Party in a post on Twitter, saying it "vehemently rejects" the sacking of the parliament. The party also accused Sirisena of robbing the "people of their rights and democracy". The act was in violation of the 19th Amendment to the constitution, which he co-sponsored.{{cite web |title=Sirisena Dissolves Parliament in Stark Violation of Constitution |url=https://www.colombotelegraph.com/index.php/sirisena-dissolves-parliament-in-stark-violation-of-constitution/ |website=Colombo Telegraph |accessdate=9 November 2018 |date=9 November 2018}} A short while later it was announced through an extraordinary gazette notice that general elections will be held on 5 January 2019, with the first meeting of the new Parliament to be held on 17 January 2019. UPFA MP [[Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena]] said "The nominations would be tendered from 9 to 26 November".{{cite web |title=General Elections to be held on Jan. 5 |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/General-Elections-to-be-held-on-Jan--158180.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=9 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109230949/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/General-Elections-to-be-held-on-Jan--158180.html# |archive-date=9 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} The JVP has accused Sirisena of trying to consolidate his power grab. The election date was announced even before preparing the government's annual budget for the next fiscal year in 2019.{{cite web |title=Elections commission ready for elections at any given time – Sri Lanka Latest News |url=https://www.newsfirst.lk/2018/11/10/elections-commission-ready-for-elections-at-any-given-time/ |website=Newsfirst |accessdate=11 November 2018 |date=10 November 2018}} Sirisena inducted more cabinet ministers prior to signing the order to dissolve the parliament. Supporters of Ranil Wickremesinghe were in the process of preparing legal papers to challenge the latest move in the country's Supreme Court. ====Sri Lanka Freedom Party Split==== Succeeding the dissolution of parliament and the announcement of snap elections, Mahinda Rajapaksa and 44 other members of parliament on 11 November defected from the [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party]], led by President Maithripala Sirisena, to join the [[Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna]] (SLPP). The SLPP was formed in 2016 by [[Basil Rajapaksa]], younger brother of Mahinda. A member of the SLPP said that 65 out of 82 Sri Lanka Freedom Party MPs will eventually join Rajapaksa's party.{{cite web |title=PM Rajapaksa obtains SLPP membership |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/PM-Rajapaksa-obtains-SLPP-membership-158200.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=14 November 2018 }}{{cite web |title=Prime Minister Mahinda obtains membership of Podujana Peramuna |url=http://www.hirunews.lk/203995/prime-minister-mahinda-obtains-membership-of-podujana-peramuna |website=Hiru News |accessdate=14 November 2018 }} Other prominent defectors include [[Mahindananda Aluthgamage]], [[Rohitha Abeygunawardena]], [[Anura Priyadharshana Yapa]], [[Johnston Fernando]] and [[Namal Rajapaksa]].{{cite web |title=MR joins the SLPP – Sri Lanka Latest News |url=https://www.newsfirst.lk/2018/11/11/mr-joins-the-slpp/ |website=Sri Lanka News – Newsfirst {{!}} Breaking News and Latest News provider {{!}} Political {{!}} Sports {{!}} International {{!}} Business |accessdate=14 November 2018 |date=11 November 2018}} Namal Rajapaksa said relating to the defections, "We will strive to create a broader coalition with many stakeholders under the leadership of Maithripala Sirisena & Mahinda Rajapaksa to face the upcoming General Election and come out victorious."{{cite web |title=Sri Lanka : Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa obtains membership of SLPP |url=http://www.colombopage.com/archive_18B/Nov11_1541926137CH.php |website=''colombopage.com'' |accessdate=14 November 2018}} ====Supreme Court stays proclamation dissolving parliament==== [[File:Supreme Court Colombo.jpg|250px|thumb|right|The Supreme Court Complex]] On 12 November, twelve [[Right to petition|Fundamental Right petitions]] were submitted to the [[Supreme Court of Sri Lanka]] challenging the president's decree sacking parliament and calling a snap election, by the UNP, TNA, JVP, SLMC and others including Prof [[Ratnajeevan Hoole]], a member of the [[Election Commission of Sri Lanka|Election Commission]]. Arguing that Sirisena's actions were unconstitutional, illegal and against the people of Sri Lanka, Hoole demanded the restoration of status quo prevailing prior to 26 October. Hoole's position strengthens the argument of 11 other petitions.{{cite web |title=Sri Lanka Election Commissioner says sacking of parliament illegal |url=https://economynext.com/Sri_Lanka_Election_Commissioner_says_sacking_of_parliament_illegal-3-12566.html |website=''economynext.com'' |accessdate=14 November 2018 }} These were taken up for hearing on the same day by a three member bench of the Supreme Court consisting of the Chief Justice [[Nalin Perera]], Justices [[Prasanna Jayawardena]] and [[Priyantha Jayawardena]].{{cite web |title=Dissolution of parliament: Petitions to be taken up today |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Dissolution-of-parliament-Petitions-to-be-taken-up-today-158227.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=14 November 2018 }} Responding to the petitions, Attorney General Jayantha Jayasuriya made submissions stating that "the court had no jurisdiction to hear and determine the Fundamental Rights petitions against the dissolution of Parliament".{{cite web |title=Court has no jurisdiction to hear FR petitions against dissolution: AG |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Court-has-no-jurisdiction-to-hear-FR-petitions-against-dissolution-AG-158282.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=14 November 2018 }} On the same day, 5 petitions by Prof [[G. L. Peiris]], Minister [[Udaya Gammanpila]], Minister [[Vasudeva Nanayakkara]] and two others supporting the dissolution of parliament were filed at the Supreme Court. However, in the evening the three Judge bench issued an interim order till 7 December staying the proclamation issued by President Sirisena to dissolve parliament and granted leave to proceed with the Fundamental Rights petitions that challenged the President's dissolving parliament.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/SC-stays-proclamation-dissolving-parliament--158295.html|title=SC stays proclamation dissolving parliament}} Following the stay order of the Supreme Court, President Sirisena convened the [[National Security Council (Sri Lanka)|National Security Council]] at the Presidential Secretariat; where he ordered the police and armed forces to maintain the peace in the country.{{cite web |title=President convenes National Security Council |url=http://www.adaderana.lk/news/51412/president-convenes-national-security-council |website=adaderana.lk |accessdate=14 November 2018 }} Soon after the IGP Jayasundara ordered senior police officers to maintain the law and order in the country.{{cite web |title=Police Chief orders to maintain law & order |url=http://www.adaderana.lk/news/51413/police-chief-orders-to-maintain-law-order |website=adaderana.lk |accessdate=14 November 2018 }} ===Parliamentary clashes=== ====1st Motion of no confidence==== {{external media | float = right | width = 250 | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V_oX0zvdimc Sri Lankan parliament session and 1st no-confidence motion], YouTube video }} The Speaker office stated on 13 November, following the stay order from the Supreme Court, that Parliament would convene on 14 November as per the gazette issued by President Sirisena on 4 November.{{cite web |title=Parliament meets tomorrow: Speaker |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Parliament-meets-tomorrow-Speaker-158301.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=14 November 2018 }} On 14 November, Sri Lankan parliament passed a [[Motion of no confidence|no-confidence motion]] against Mahinda Rajapaksa. Amid shouting, speaker [[Karu Jayasuriya]] took a [[voice vote]]. Wickremesinghe said he submitted a petition carrying signatures of 122 MPs who support the no-confidence motion.{{cite news |title=Sri Lanka MPs pass no-confidence vote against disputed PM Rajapaksa |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/nov/14/sri-lanka-parliament-no-confidence-pm-mahinda-rajapaksa |work=The Guardian |date=14 November 2018}} Jayasuriya confirmed that the no-confidence motion against Rajapaksa had support of 122 members in the 225-member house.{{cite news |title=Sri Lanka showdown looms as new PM loses confidence vote |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sri-lanka-politics/sri-lanka-showdown-looms-as-new-pm-loses-confidence-vote-idUSKCN1NJ0FF |agency=Reuters |date=14 November 2018}} ====2nd Motion of no confidence==== ===Transferral of Nishantha Silva=== Since the start of the crisis, President Sirisena has taken the police under his direct control.{{cite web |title=Sri Lanka Removes Top Cop Investigating Rajapaksa Family Amid Crisis |url=https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/sri-lanka-president-maithripala-sirisena-removes-top-cop-nishantha-silva-investigating-rajapakse-fam-1949998 |website=NDTV.com |accessdate=20 November 2018}} Inspector of Police Nishantha Silva is the officer in charge of [[Criminal Investigation Department (Sri Lanka)|Criminal Investigation Department]]'s (CID) Organised Crimes Investigation Unit. Silva is handling investigations into major incidents including those during the Rajapaksa administration, most notably the abduction and the assault of Journalist Keith Noyahr, in 2008 and the murder of [[Lasantha Wickrematunge]] in 2009, in addition to at least 60 crimes committed by the [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam|LTTE]]. He is also investigating the rape and the murder of student Sivaloganathan Vithya and the abduction of 11 youths in Colombo, in 2008-09 where Chief of Defence Staff [[Admiral]] [[Ravindra Wijegunaratne]] is allegedly involved in harbouring a suspect of the abduction. Mahinda Rajapaksa, [[Rajapaksa family|his family]] and associates are directly connected to these investigations, and as Silva pursued inquiries into them, on 18 November he was transferred by IGP [[Pujith Jayasundara]] on the orders of President Sirisena to the Negombo Division with "immediate effect on service requirements".{{cite web |title=Police Commission cancels transfer of CID Inspector Nishantha Silva {{!}} FT Online |url=http://www.ft.lk/front-page/Police-Commission-cancels-transfer--of-CID-Inspector-Nishantha-Silva/44-667198 |website=www.ft.lk |accessdate=20 November 2018 |language=en}}{{cite web |title=CID’s IP Nishantha Silva transferred |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/CID-s-IP-Nishantha-Silva-transferred-158572.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=20 November 2018 |language=en}} Silva had just secured an arrest order for Admiral Wijegunaratne when he was shifted. Wijegunaratne, however has retained the office of Chief of Defence Staff. [[Gotabhaya Rajapaksa]], the Former defence secretary and brother of the former president, is being investigated on allegations of defrauding the state and was indicted in September. Silva was also investigating Gotabhaya for alleged corruption in aircraft purchases from Ukraine during his time in the Rajapaksa administration.{{cite web |title=Sri Lanka reinstates top detective after outcry |url=https://economynext.com/Sri_Lanka_reinstates_top_detective_after_outcry-3-12673.html |website=economynext.com |accessdate=20 November 2018 |language=en}} In response to the transferal Silva had appealed to the National Police Commission (NPC). The Commission requested a report from IGP Pujith Jayasundara as to why the officer handling several high profile investigations had been transferred.{{cite web |title=CID’s IP Nishantha Silva appeals to NPC |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/CID-s-IP-Nishantha-Silva-appeals-to-NPC-158626.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=20 November 2018 |language=en}} The intervention by the NPC prompted IGP Jayasundara to reverse his order and withdraw the transfer, on the 19th, allowing Silva to continue in the same capacity.{{cite web |title=Transfer of CID’s IP Nishantha Silva cancelled |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Transfer-of-CID-s-IP-Nishantha-Silva-cancelled-158630.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=20 November 2018 |language=en}} It was learnt in a letter to IGP Jayasundara, written by CID Director Senior DIG Ravi Seneviratne that it was Admiral Wijegunaratne who had orchestrated the transferal by framing allegations against Silva of maintaining connections with the LTTE, during the last security council meeting chaired by President Sirisena.{{cite web |title=Sirisena-Wijegunaratne Sinister Attempt To Axe Nishantha Silva Uncovered: IGP Withdraws Transfer Order |url=https://www.colombotelegraph.com/index.php/sirisena-wijegunaratne-sinister-attempt-to-axe-nishantha-silva-uncovered-igp-withdraws-transfer-order/ |website=Colombo Telegraph |accessdate=20 November 2018 |date=20 November 2018}} The daughter of journalist Lasantha Wickrematunge, Ahimsa wrote to the President against the [[obstruction of justice]].{{cite web |title=Slain Sri Lanka editor's daughter writes to President |url=https://economynext.com/Slain_Sri_Lanka_editor_s_daughter_write_to_President-3-12674.html |website=economynext.com |accessdate=20 November 2018 |language=en}} ==Protests== ===Pro-democracy protests=== The UNP held a pro-democracy protest near the [[Temple Trees]] on 31 October, where thousands of Sri Lankans have taken to the streets urging President Sirisena to uphold democracy.{{cite web |title=UNP holds protest demanding democracy |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/-UNP-holds-protest-demanding-democracy-157626.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181101140048/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/-UNP-holds-protest-demanding-democracy-157626.html# |archive-date=1 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} The JVP held protest rally at Nugegoda on 1 November demanding the president to reconvene parliament immediately and to restore democracy in the country.{{cite web |title=JVP protest at Nugegoda |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/JVP-protest-at-Nugegoda--157755.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104010426/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/JVP-protest-at-Nugegoda--157755.html# |archive-date=4 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} Tens of thousands of Sri Lankans marched Monday 5 November in support of a new government of Mahinda Rajapaksa and Maithripala Sirisena. Sri Lanka Police estimated 120,000 people attended the rally.{{cite web |title=Sri Lankans March in Support of Strongman Mahinda Rajapaksa's Return to Power |url=http://time.com/5445670/sri-lanka-march-mahinda-rajapaksa/ |website=Time |accessdate=11 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107054213/http://time.com/5445670/sri-lanka-march-mahinda-rajapaksa/# |archive-date=7 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} ===Violence=== Rival groups supporting Mahinda Rajapaksa and Ranil Wickremesinghe have been gathering at different locations around [[Colombo]]. Hundreds of supporters of Wickremesinghe have gathered around Temple Trees and say they will stay there to protect the ousted Prime Minister. So far demonstrations have been mostly peaceful, but Speaker Jayasuriya, and others, have warned of a "blood bath" if Parliament was not permitted to meet and end the constitutional crisis. With the rushed swearing in of Rajapaksa, Rajapaksa loyalists stormed two state-owned television networks which they regarded loyal to Wickremesinghe and the sitting government and forced them off the air. Trade unions linked to Rajapaksa's party have also been blocking access to ministers who are from the United National Party. On Sunday 28 October, the bodyguards of a deposed government minister opened fire on a crowd of protestors resulting in the death of one person.{{cite web |last1=Athas |first1=Iqbal |last2=George |first2=Steve |title=Sri Lanka constitutional crisis turns violent |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/10/29/asia/sri-lanka-constitutional-crisis-intl/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=31 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181031133254/https://edition.cnn.com/2018/10/29/asia/sri-lanka-constitutional-crisis-intl/index.html# |archive-date=31 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} The first reported outbreak of violence occurred at the [[Ceylon Petroleum Corporation]] (CPC), which houses the headquarters of national oil and gas company, resulted in a shooting between members of the [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party]] CPC Trade Union and the personal security detail of deposed petroleum minister, [[Arjuna Ranatunga]]. Crowds loyal to the president attempted to prevent Ranatunga from entering the government building in Colombo as he was attempting to retrieve belongings from the CPC offices. One union member was killed and two or three injured by shots fired by a member of the police MSD security detail as the crowd tried to take Ranatunga hostage. Ranatunga was rushed into the building in the immediate aftermath of the shooting. The SLFP CPC Trade Union went on strike until Ranatunga was arrested, causing long queues at filling stations. Ranatunga was dressed in a helmet and camouflage, and escorted by the [[Special Task Force]], dozens of regular police were deployed in order to pacify a still-agitated crowd. He was arrested by police on 30 October, and was subsequently released on bail. The strike was called off. One security member was arrested and an investigation has begun into the incident, police have confirmed.{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/25115028/arjuna-ranatunga-bail-shooting-incident|title=Arjuna Ranatunga out on bail after shooting incident|last1=Fernando|first1=Andrew|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=31 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181031215409/http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/25115028/arjuna-ranatunga-bail-shooting-incident#|archive-date=31 October 2018|dead-url=no}} After being rescued by police commandos, later on Sunday speaking to reporters Ranatunga said his bodyguards opened fire because the crowd "They came to kill me – I state this responsibly – and you can check the CCTV footage," "For the first time, I feared for my life. I thought of my children and my family."" ==Reactions== ===Economic=== The [[Colombo Stock Exchange|Sri Lanka Stock Exchange]] recorded significant growth during the week.{{cite web |title=Sri Lankan stock surge; ASPI crosses 6,000 mark |url=http://bizenglish.adaderana.lk/sri-lankan-stock-surge-aspi-crosses-6000-mark/ |website=bizenglish.adaderana.lk |publisher=adaderana.lk. |accessdate=1 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181102005722/http://bizenglish.adaderana.lk/sri-lankan-stock-surge-aspi-crosses-6000-mark/# |archive-date=2 November 2018 |dead-url=no }}{{cite web|title=Stock market responds to political change|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Stock-market-responds-to-political-change-157541.html|website=dailymirror.lk|accessdate=1 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181029085840/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Stock-market-responds-to-political-change-157541.html#|archive-date=29 October 2018|dead-url=no}} However, the [[Sri Lankan rupee|rupee]] reached a record low during the week, but was boosted by [[Central Bank of Sri Lanka|Central Bank]] dollar sales.{{Cite web |url=http://www.ft.lk/front-page/Rupee-rebounds-from-record-low--stocks-hit-near-2-month-high/44-665983# |title=Rupee rebounds from record low; stocks hit near 2-month high |access-date=2 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181102031323/http://www.ft.lk/front-page/Rupee-rebounds-from-record-low--stocks-hit-near-2-month-high/44-665983# |archive-date=2 November 2018 |dead-url=no }} {{cite web |title=Sri Lanka : U.S., Japan freeze aid to Sri Lanka over political crisis, sacked PM says |url=http://www.colombopage.com/archive_18B/Nov04_1541343999CH.php |website=''colombopage.com'' |accessdate=14 November 2018}} In the wake of the political crisis and doubts about the future of democracy in the nation, the United States and Japanese governments froze more than a billion US dollars worth of development aid. The [[European Union]] also warned that if it did not stick to commitments on national reconciliation, it could withdraw duty-free concessions for Sri Lankan exports. On 20th November credit rating agency [[Moody's Corporation|Moody's]] released a statement downgrading the Sri Lankan Government's foreign currency issuer and senior unsecured ratings to B2 from B1 and changed the outlook to stable from negative. Moody's says the downgrade was driven by the "ongoing tightening in external and domestic financing conditions and low reserve adequacy, exacerbated most recently by a political crisis which seems likely to have a lasting impact on policy".{{cite web |title=Moody's downgrades Sri Lanka's ratings to B2, changes outlook to stable from negative |url=https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-downgrades-Sri-Lankas-ratings-to-B2-changes-outlook-to--PR_391459 |website=Moodys.com |accessdate=20 November 2018 |date=20 November 2018}}{{cite web |title=Moody's downgrades SL's ratings, changes outlook to negative |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Moody-s-downgrades-SL-s-ratings-changes-outlook-to-negative-158639.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=20 November 2018 |language=en}} ===Political=== ====Domestic responses==== ;Political parties * [[Ceylon Workers' Congress]] (CWC) – Two members of the CWC have pledged their support to Mahinda Rajapaksa on 27 October.{{cite web |title=CWC supports MR |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/CWC-supports-MR-157478.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181028151619/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/CWC-supports-MR-157478.html# |archive-date=28 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} * [[Sri Lanka Muslim Congress]] (SLMC) – Has pledged its support to [[United National Party]] on 27 October.{{cite web |title=SLMC supports Ranil |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/SLMC-supports-Ranil-157479.html |website=Daily Mirror |accessdate=3 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181028151558/http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/SLMC-supports-Ranil-157479.html# |archive-date=28 October 2018 |dead-url=no }} * [[Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna]] (JVP) – The leader of the JVP [[Anura Kumara Dissanayaka]], has stated that the JVP will not support any party to form a government and that the "President should
